titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Millard Fillmore letter 1977.511
titlestmt.author: Nicholas Pavlik
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection was originally processed and described as part of the project, "Uncovering the Secrets of Brooklyn's 19th Century Past: Creation to Consolidation," funded by the Council on Library and Information Resources, with additional support from The Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-12-01 19:28:46 +0000.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.abstract: One 1840 letter from Millard Fillmore, New York State Representative in the 26th United States Congress, promoting the election of William Henry Harrison for the office of U.S. President.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection consists of a single document.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Millard Fillmore letter, 1840, 1977.511, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Public Library, Center for Brooklyn History.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was rehoused and the finding aid revised by Dee Bowers in 2023.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Circular letter from Millard Fillmore, New York State Representative in the 26th United States Congress, promoting the election of William Henry Harrison for the office of U.S. President and commenting on the administration of current President Martin Van Buren. The letter is sent from Washington, D.C. and includes marginal notes by Elijah Knight of Erie County, N.Y., who forwarded the letter to F.D. Bordman of Medina, Orleans County, N.Y. It is dated February 19, 1840. Fillmore himself would later serve as U.S. President from 1850 to 1853.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: This item is in the public domain. While many items at the Center for Brooklyn History are unrestricted, we do not own reproduction rights to all materials. Be aware of the several kinds of rights that might apply: copyright, licensing and trademarks. The researcher assumes all responsibility for copyright questions.
